content: Alright, gather round. I need to explain something about my kite experiment because people keep getting it wrong. ðŸ§µ A thread:
historicalContext: Franklin's famous kite experiment in June 1752 proved that lightning was electrical in nature. Contrary to popular belief, he was not struck by lightning.

content: First: I did NOT get struck by lightning. If I had, I would be dead. Very, very dead. The whole point was to prove lightning IS electricity WITHOUT dying.
The kite was flown NEAR a storm, not IN it. There's a key attached to the string. When the string got wet from rain, I touched my knuckle to the key. Felt a spark. Electricity confirmed.
Do NOT try this at home. Two men in Europe attempted to replicate my experiment and were killed. Science is wonderful but it will absolutely murder you if you're careless.
historicalContext: Georg Wilhelm Richmann was killed in 1753 attempting to replicate Franklin's experiment in St. Petersburg.

content:
The REAL invention was the lightning rod. I figured if buildings could channel lightning safely into the ground, they'd stop burning down.

You're welcome, every tall building ever built. /end
historicalContext: Franklin invented the lightning rod in 1752. It was one of the first practical applications of electrical research.

content: People keep asking me about writing the Declaration. Fine. Here's how it actually went. Thread:
historicalContext: Jefferson was chosen to write the Declaration because of his reputation as an eloquent writer.

content: Adams asked me to do it. He said I write better than him. I said he should do it because he's more respected. We went back and forth. He won.
Wrote the whole thing in 17 days. Rented a room at Graff's house on Market Street. Second floor. Nice and quiet except when it wasn't.
historicalContext: Jefferson rented rooms from Jacob Graff Jr. at Market and 7th Street in Philadelphia.

content: Then Congress edited it. They cut about a quarter of it. Including my whole section on slavery. I'm still upset about that.
historicalContext: Jefferson's original draft included a passage condemning slavery and the slave trade. Southern delegates insisted it be removed.

content: Franklin sat next to me during the editing. He noticed I was getting upset with all the changes. He told me a story about a hatter to calm me down. Didn't really help but I appreciated it. /end
historicalContext: Franklin reportedly told Jefferson a story about a hatter who kept simplifying his sign until only a picture of a hat remained, to console him about Congress's edits.

content: Everyone remembers the crossing. Nobody remembers what led up to it. Let me explain. Thread:
We had just lost New York. Then New Jersey. The army was falling apart. Enlistments were ending December 31st. Most men were going home.
historicalContext: After a series of defeats in late 1776, the Continental Army had shrunk from 20,000 to about 2,400 soldiers.

content: We needed a victory. Something. Anything. Trenton had a Hessian garrison. 1,500 men. They were professional soldiers. We were farmers with muskets.
Christmas night. Snow storm. We crossed in boats through ice. Two men froze to death during the march. We arrived at dawn.
historicalContext: The crossing took 9 hours in brutal conditions. The army marched 9 miles to Trenton in sleet and snow.

content:
We captured 900 Hessians. Lost 0 men in battle. Only 4 wounded.

The Revolution continued. That's what mattered. /end
historicalContext: The Battle of Trenton was a decisive American victory that revived the flagging Revolutionary cause.
